trans-unit.source: Skyboxes and backgrounds
trans-unit.target: Skyboxes and backgrounds

trans-unit.source: Beginner Designer Programmer
trans-unit.target: Beginner Designer Programmer

trans-unit.source: Skyboxes are backgrounds that create the illusion of space and distance. Typical skybox backgrounds include skies, clouds, mountains, and other scenery. As skyboxes are prerendered, they require little GPU and CPU.
trans-unit.target: Skyboxes are backgrounds that create the illusion of space and distance. Typical skybox backgrounds include skies, clouds, mountains, and other scenery. As skyboxes are prerendered, they require little GPU and CPU.

trans-unit.source: You can use cubemaps or 360° panoramic textures as skyboxes. You can also use them to light the scene.
trans-unit.target: You can use cubemaps or 360° panoramic textures as skyboxes. You can also use them to light the scene.

trans-unit.source: !Note Currently, Stride doesn't support skydomes or local skyboxes.
trans-unit.target: !Note Currently, Stride doesn't support skydomes or local skyboxes.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can display a 2D background, which is often useful for 2D games.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can display a 2D background, which is often useful for 2D games.

trans-unit.source: Cubemaps
trans-unit.target: Cubemaps

trans-unit.source: A cubemap is a six-sided texture. When these textures are assembled in a cube around the scene, the cubemap simulates spacious 3D surroundings.
trans-unit.target: A cubemap is a six-sided texture. When these textures are assembled in a cube around the scene, the cubemap simulates spacious 3D surroundings.

trans-unit.source: Create a cubemap in Game Studio
trans-unit.target: Create a cubemap in Game Studio

trans-unit.source: You can capture a cubemap from a position in your scene.
trans-unit.target: You can capture a cubemap from a position in your scene.

trans-unit.source: In the scene editor, position the camera at the point where you want to capture the cubemap. The direction the camera faces doesn't matter, only the position.
trans-unit.target: In the scene editor, position the camera at the point where you want to capture the cubemap. The direction the camera faces doesn't matter, only the position.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you should capture cubemaps at the center of your scene to create the best all-round view.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you should capture cubemaps at the center of your scene to create the best all-round view.

trans-unit.source: In the scene editor toolbar, open the Lighting options menu.
trans-unit.target: In the scene editor toolbar, open the Lighting options menu.

trans-unit.source: Lighting options
trans-unit.target: Lighting options

trans-unit.source: Under Cubemap, click Generate.
trans-unit.target: Under Cubemap, click Generate.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the location on disk you want to save the cubemap, specify a name, and click Save.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the location on disk you want to save the cubemap, specify a name, and click Save.

trans-unit.source: !Tip We recommend you save the cubemap in your project Resources folder. For more information, see Organize your files in version control.
trans-unit.target: !Tip We recommend you save the cubemap in your project Resources folder. For more information, see Organize your files in version control.

trans-unit.source: Game Studio creates a cubemap .dds file in the location you specified.
trans-unit.target: Game Studio creates a cubemap .dds file in the location you specified.

trans-unit.source: Create a skybox
trans-unit.target: Create a skybox

trans-unit.source: To create a skybox, add a cubemap or 360° panoramic texture to a background component.
trans-unit.target: To create a skybox, add a cubemap or 360° panoramic texture to a background component.

trans-unit.source: Stride includes an entity with a background component in the project by default. Only one background can be active in a scene at a time. If there are multiple backgrounds, Stride only loads the first.
trans-unit.target: Stride includes an entity with a background component in the project by default. Only one background can be active in a scene at a time. If there are multiple backgrounds, Stride only loads the first.

trans-unit.source: You can add background components to as many entities as you need. You might want to include more than one background, for example, if you want to switch skyboxes at runtime.
trans-unit.target: You can add background components to as many entities as you need. You might want to include more than one background, for example, if you want to switch skyboxes at runtime.

trans-unit.source: Add a background entity
trans-unit.target: Add a background entity

trans-unit.source: In the Scene view, select the entity you want to add the component to.
trans-unit.target: In the Scene view, select the entity you want to add the component to.

trans-unit.source: This can be an empty entity. Its position in the scene doesn't matter.
trans-unit.target: This can be an empty entity. Its position in the scene doesn't matter.

trans-unit.source: In the Property Grid (on the right by default), click Add component and select Background.
trans-unit.target: In the Property Grid (on the right by default), click Add component and select Background.

trans-unit.source: Add background component
trans-unit.target: Add background component

trans-unit.source: Under Texture, select the cubemap or 360° panoramic texture you want to use in the skybox.
trans-unit.target: Under Texture, select the cubemap or 360° panoramic texture you want to use in the skybox.

trans-unit.source: Set a 2D background
trans-unit.target: Set a 2D background

trans-unit.source: Instead of using a 3D skybox, you can display the texture as a static background. This displays the texture as a flat image that stays static no matter how you move the camera. This is often useful for 2D games.
trans-unit.target: Instead of using a 3D skybox, you can display the texture as a static background. This displays the texture as a flat image that stays static no matter how you move the camera. This is often useful for 2D games.

trans-unit.source: To do this, in the Background component properties, select 2D background.
trans-unit.target: To do this, in the Background component properties, select 2D background.
